definition: lit. chickens flying and dogs jumping (idiom)/fig. in chaos/in disarray
fowl/chicken/CL:隻|只[zhi1]/(slang) prostitute
to fly
dog/CL:隻|只[zhi1],條|条[tiao2]
to jump/to hop/to skip over/to bounce/to palpitate

sentences.english: You always leave everything off until the last minute.
sentences.chinese: 你老是拖到最后一刻才鸡飞狗跳。

sentences.english: The assembly went out of control and became a scene of turmoil.
sentences.chinese: 场面失控了，变得鸡飞狗跳，一片混乱。

sentences.english: The White House and the Pentagon would have barely stirred.
sentences.chinese: 白宫和五角大楼大概就不至于被搅得鸡飞狗跳了。

definition: lit. not even the chickens and dogs are left undisturbed (idiom)/fig. great commotion/pandemonium
to suffer a crushing defeat (idiom)/in a pitiful state/in a complete mess/to roll (with laughter)
lit. badly burned about the head (from trying to put out a fire) (idiom)/fig. hard-pressed/under pressure (from a heavy workload, creditors etc)
chaos/bungle/complete mess/shambles
billowing smoke (idiom)/foul atmosphere/(fig.) murky atmosphere/in a turmoil
to disturb/to create confusion/to make a din
to be awfully (busy etc)
lit. wind and rain sweeping through the town (idiom)/fig. a big scandal/an uproar/the talk of the town
to cover one's head and sneak away like a rat (idiom); to flee ignominiously
to create a big disturbance
in a great mess/chaotic
to wail like ghosts and howl like wolves (idiom)
rushed and muddled
noisy and in disarray/in an uproar
clamorous/noisy/sensational/very exciting
lit. dark sky and black earth (idiom)/fig. pitch dark/to black out/disorderly/troubled times
